deliberation: Considered whether the prophetic formula is purely literal or employs figurative personification/metonymy. The phrase 'the word of YHWH came to me' treats the 'word' as an agent that moves, which is conventional but still figurative.

instances.metonymy_explanation: ‘Word’ stands for the divine message/revelation itself
instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
vehicle: a ‘word’ that comes/arrives like a person or messenger
ground: the message has initiative and approaches the prophet
posture: formula stressing the authority and origin of the message
instances.explanation: The divine message is spoken of as a ‘word’ that comes to the prophet, personifying the message and using ‘word’ metonymically for God’s revelatory act.

deliberation: Examined 'son of man' and 'lift up a dirge'. 'Son of man' here functions as a standard title for Ezekiel. The expression 'שָׂא ... קִינָה' is an idiomatic collocation meaning 'utter a lamentation', not literally lift it.

instances.english_text: intone a dirge over Tyre (lit. 'lift up a dirge over Tyre')
target: Ezekiel’s prophetic act of pronouncing lament
vehicle: act of raising / bearing a burden
ground: making a lament audible and prominent
posture: command to perform a formal lament
instances.explanation: The Hebrew idiom 'lift up a lament' figuratively uses the act of lifting a burden to mean voicing or proclaiming a lamentation.

deliberation: Considered (1) Tyre ‘dwelling at the entrances of the sea’, (2) Tyre as trader with peoples, and (3) Tyre boasting 'I am perfect in beauty'. The dominant figurative elements are the personification of Tyre as a speaking female and the hyperbolic self-description of flawless beauty.

instances.english_text: O Tyre, you boasted / you said
vehicle: an individual woman who speaks and boasts
ground: Tyre exhibits pride and self-assertion like a person
instances.explanation: The city Tyre is addressed as a ‘you’ who can speak and boast, treating the city as a person, which is a clear personification.

instances.english_text: I am perfect in beauty (lit. ‘the perfection / totality of beauty’)
ground: Tyre is exceptionally attractive and splendid
instances.explanation: Tyre’s claim to be ‘the perfection of beauty’ is a hyperbolic metaphor, since no city can literally embody all beauty; it exaggerates her splendor and sets up the irony of her downfall.

deliberation: The verse continues the maritime imagery. The most distinct figurative element here is 'in the heart of the seas' for Tyre’s borders. 'Heart' is a metaphorical way to speak of the center/innermost part of the sea.

instances.english_text: Your frontiers were in the heart of the seas
ground: Tyre is situated deep within maritime space, centrally placed for trade
posture: highlighting Tyre’s prime maritime situation before its fall
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘heart of the seas’ metaphorically uses the human ‘heart’ to describe the central, deeply embedded position of Tyre in the sea and in sea-borne trade.

deliberation: Considered whether the ship-description is literal or figurative. Given that throughout the lament Tyre (a city) is addressed as ‘you’ with planks and a mast, the verse participates in the extended metaphor of Tyre as a splendid merchant ship.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּרוֹשִׁ֤ים מִשְּׂנִיר֙ בָּ֣נוּ לָ֔ךְ אֵ֖ת כׇּל־לֻחֹתָ֑יִם ... לַעֲשׂ֥וֹת תֹּ֖רֶן עָלָֽיִךְ
instances.english_text: From cypress trees of Senir they fashioned your planks; they took a cedar from Lebanon to make a mast for you
vehicle: a finely constructed seagoing vessel with planks and mast
ground: both Tyre and a great ship are built from select materials for long-distance trade and display of prestige
posture: initial admiration that sets up dramatic irony when the ‘ship’ is wrecked
instances.explanation: The city of Tyre is described as if she were a ship whose planks and mast are made from fine timbers; this continues the extended metaphor of Tyre as a magnificent merchant vessel.

deliberation: The whole verse speaks of oars and decks in relation to 'you' (feminine Tyre). This clearly extends the ship-image applied to the city, not just describing one literal ship.

instances.hebrew_text: אַלּוֹנִים֙ מִבָּשָׁ֔ן עָשׂ֖וּ מִשּׁוֹטָ֑יִךְ קַרְשֵׁ֤ךְ עָֽשׂוּ־שֵׁן֙ ... מֵאִיֵּ֖י כִּתִּיִּֽם
instances.english_text: From oak trees of Bashan they made your oars; of boxwood from the isles of Kittim, inlaid with ivory, they made your decks
vehicle: a richly equipped ship with oars and ivory-inlaid decks
ground: luxury materials and design serve long-range sea trade
posture: depicting Tyre’s former glory in order to heighten the pathos of her ruin
instances.explanation: By describing ‘your oars’ and ‘your decks’ made from fine woods and ivory, the prophet metaphorically depicts Tyre itself as an exquisitely outfitted ship.

deliberation: The verse continues nautical features (sails, awnings) attached to the second-feminine singular ‘you’. The city as ship metaphor continues.

instances.hebrew_text: שֵׁשׁ־בְּרִקְמָ֤ה מִמִּצְרַ֙יִם֙ הָיָ֣ה מִפְרָשֵׂ֔ךְ ... תְּכֵ֧לֶת וְאַרְגָּמָ֛ן ... הָיָ֥ה מְכַסֵּֽךְ
instances.english_text: Embroidered linen from Egypt was the cloth that served you for sails; of blue and purple from the coasts of Elishah were your awnings
target: Tyre’s international prestige and display of wealth
vehicle: a ship whose visible parts (sails, awnings) are made of luxurious textiles
ground: both Tyre and such a ship present an impressive, richly adorned exterior to observers
posture: picturing magnificence that is about to be reversed
instances.explanation: Describing ‘your sail’ and ‘your covering’ in terms of embroidered linen and purple cloth extends the depiction of Tyre as a lavishly decorated vessel on display before the nations.

deliberation: Again, the text attributes rowers and pilots to Tyre herself, continuing the conceptualization of the city as a ship with a crew rather than a static piece of real estate.

instances.hebrew_text: יֹשְׁבֵ֤י צִידוֹן֙ וְאַרְוַ֔ד הָי֥וּ שָׁטִ֖ים לָ֑ךְ ... הֵ֖מָּה חֹבְלָֽיִךְ
instances.english_text: The inhabitants of Sidon and Arvad were your rowers; your skilled men, O Tyre, were within you, they were your pilots
vehicle: a ship’s rowing crew and pilots navigating at sea
ground: both require specialized personnel to operate and direct complex movement
dependence on skilled crews to conduct far-reaching voyages
posture: emphasizing Tyre’s sophisticated, multinational staffing before disaster
instances.explanation: By giving Tyre ‘rowers’ and ‘pilots’, the prophet furthers the metaphor that sees the city itself as a great trading ship staffed by expert seamen.

deliberation: The terms for ‘repairs’ (בִּדְקֵךְ) and the presence of all the ships ‘in you’ fit the ongoing ship portrayal. This verse does not introduce a new kind of figurative language but continues the ship metaphor applied to Tyre.

instances.hebrew_text: זִקְנֵ֨י גְבַ֤ל ... הָ֣יוּ בָ֔ךְ מַחֲזִיקֵ֖י בִּדְקֵ֑ךְ
instances.english_text: Gebal’s elders and artisans were within you, making your repairs
vehicle: a ship whose seams and breaches are repaired by craftsmen
ground: both need expert upkeep to remain seaworthy/viable
continuous repair to withstand stresses of trade and time
posture: shows how well-supported Tyre’s ‘vessel’ was, heightening the shock of its eventual wreck
instances.explanation: Describing Tyre’s ‘breaches’ being repaired by the elders of Gebal continues the metaphor of Tyre as a ship whose physical integrity must be maintained.

deliberation: The verse lists foreign troops and their armor. 'They lent splendor to you' is evaluative but not strongly figurative; shields literally hung on city walls in the ancient Near East. No clear metaphor, simile, or idiom beyond normal description.

The military imagery is largely literal. However, the statement 'they perfected your beauty' echoes v.3 and v.4 and participates in the conceptualization of Tyre as a beautiful, adorned being (often a feminine city). I treat this as a continuation of the ‘Tyre as beautiful woman/adorned entity’ metaphor.

instances.english_text: They perfected your beauty
vehicle: a beauty fully completed, leaving nothing lacking
ground: Tyre appears complete and flawless in strength and splendor
posture: heightening the contrast between former perfection and coming ruin
instances.explanation: Saying others ‘perfected your beauty’ goes beyond literal description of defenses and ascribes to Tyre an ideal, completed beauty, echoing a metaphorical portrayal of the city as a perfectly adorned being.

deliberation: This verse lists Tarshish trading with Tyre in specific metals. The language is straightforward commercial description with no clear figurative phrases distinct from the broader context.
Describes trade in 'human souls/persons' and copper vessels. Though morally charged, the terms are literal (slave trade). No metaphor, simile, or idiomatic expression appears.
Lists horses, riders, and mules as trade items. The phraseology is concrete and literal with no distinct figurative devices.
Most of the verse is a literal trade list. The phrase 'סְחֹרַת יָדֵךְ' ('the merchandise/trade of your hand') uses 'hand' metonymically for Tyre’s power/control or activity in trade.

instances.english_text: many coastlands [were] the merchandise/trade of your hand
vehicle: the ‘hand’ as the organ of action and control
ground: a person’s hand represents their ability to act and exercise control
Tyre’s ‘hand’ signifies its exerted power over trade
posture: stressing how far Tyre’s control in trade extended
instances.explanation: Here ‘hand’ stands metonymically for Tyre’s active control or power, so that the ‘merchandise of your hand’ means the trade under Tyre’s control.

deliberation: A catalog of luxurious goods Aram traded with Tyre. The wording is straightforward; no explicit figurative device beyond general evaluative tone.
Another trade list (wheat, honey, oil, balm). The verse is literal; no metaphors or idioms distinct from normal commercial language.
Damascus’ trade in wine and wool is described. The repeated reference to 'your wealth of merchandise' is evaluative but not figurative in form. No distinct metaphor or idiom identified.
Lists Vedan and Javan trading polished iron, cassia, and calamus. All terms appear to be concrete; no figurative expression stands out.
Dedan’s trade in saddlecloths for riding is literal, with no metaphorical or idiomatic turn of phrase.

Describes Arabia and Kedar trading livestock. There is a possible echo of 'trade of your hand' from v.15 ('סֹחֲרֵי יָדֵךְ'), which again uses 'hand' metonymically for control/agency. I treat this as a parallel metonymy.

instances.english_text: they were traders of your hand
target: those operating under Tyre’s economic influence
vehicle: hand as the instrument of action and power
ground: the ‘hand’ commonly stands for the exertion of power or activity
designating sub-traders as belonging to Tyre’s sphere of action
posture: underlining Tyre’s reach into Arabian trade
quietly triumphal yet within a lamenting context
instances.explanation: The phrase calls Arabia and Kedar ‘traders of your hand’, using ‘hand’ metonymically for Tyre’s active power and sphere of operation.

deliberation: Another literal list of merchants and goods (spices, stones, gold). No explicit figurative device separate from the overall lament imagery.
Simply names cities and peoples that traded with Tyre. Straightforward geography and commerce, no evident figurative language.

Describes choice fabrics and garments as merchandise. Though rich, the language is literal, focusing on types of cloth and their handling; no clear metaphor beyond those already noted in previous verses.

The syntax combines literal ships of Tarshish with the feminized ‘you’ (Tyre) being ‘filled’ and ‘made heavy’ in the heart of the seas. This returns explicitly to the ship-as-Tyre metaphor already developed.

instances.hebrew_text: אֳנִיּ֣וֹת תַּרְשִׁ֔ישׁ שָׁרוֹתַ֖יִךְ מַעֲרָבֵ֑ךְ וַתִּמָּלְאִ֧י וַֽתִּכְבְּדִ֛י מְאֹ֖ד בְּלֵ֥ב יַמִּֽים
instances.english_text: The ships of Tarshish were in the service of your trade. So you were full and richly laden on the high seas (lit. ‘in the heart of the seas’)
target: Tyre’s economic system laden with wealth and dependencies
vehicle: a ship heavy-laden with cargo in the middle of the sea
ground: both are filled to capacity with valuable goods dependent on sea routes
weight, fullness, exposure on the sea
posture: portraying overwhelming prosperity as a prelude to catastrophic loss
instances.explanation: By saying Tyre was ‘full’ and ‘heavy’ in the ‘heart of the seas’, the prophet pictures the city as a ship overladen with cargo, deep at sea, ready for wreck.

deliberation: The verse clearly focuses on Tyre-as-ship in 'mighty waters' broken by an east wind. This is a vivid metaphor for the city’s destruction through international forces (often symbolized by the east wind).

instances.metonymy_explanation: The east wind stands for destructive forces of judgment (invading powers)
instances.hebrew_text: בְּמַ֤יִם רַבִּים֙ הֱבִא֔וּךְ הַשָּׁטִ֖ים אֹתָ֑ךְ ר֚וּחַ הַקָּדִ֔ים שְׁבָרֵ֖ךְ בְּלֵ֥ב יַמִּֽים
instances.english_text: Your oarsmen brought you out into the mighty waters; the east wind wrecked you on the high seas
target: Tyre’s historical destiny and eventual downfall
vehicle: a ship driven into deep waters and shattered by a violent east wind
ground: both involve being exposed and then destroyed by overwhelming forces
posture: interpreting Tyre’s fall as a divinely driven, catastrophic wreck
instances.explanation: Tyre is depicted as a ship carried into great waters and smashed by an east wind, a metaphor for how international and divine forces will bring the proud trading power to ruin.

deliberation: The piling up of terms for wealth, crews, and warriors all 'falling in the heart of the seas' on the day of collapse continues the shipwreck imagery, now emphasized as a comprehensive sinking of all that constituted Tyre.

instances.english_text: shall go down / fall into the depths of the sea (lit. ‘in the heart of the seas’) on the day of your downfall
target: total collapse of Tyre’s economy, personnel, and defenses
vehicle: a ship whose cargo and crew all sink into the deep sea
ground: nothing is salvaged; all is swallowed up
posture: emphasizing the thoroughness of the coming judgment
instances.explanation: By saying that all of Tyre’s wealth and people ‘fall in the heart of the seas’ on the day of her fall, the prophet uses shipwreck imagery to depict a total, overwhelming destruction.

deliberation: The Hebrew likely means ‘the open lands/coastlands shall quake’ at the cry of the pilots. This is hyperbolic, quasi-personified language of the land reacting to the lament, a common prophetic way to mark the cosmic impact of judgment.

instances.english_text: At the outcry of your pilots the open lands shall quake
target: the emotional and political shock of Tyre’s fall
vehicle: physical quaking of land in response to a cry
ground: Tyre’s fall will shake surrounding peoples as if the ground itself trembled
posture: amplifying the impact of the judgment beyond Tyre itself
instances.explanation: The ‘open lands’ or coastlands are said to quake at the pilots’ cry, personifying the land and hyperbolically conveying the far-reaching shock caused by Tyre’s disaster.

deliberation: Describes sailors leaving their ships and standing on land, preparing to lament. The scene is vivid but not phrased figuratively; it functions as narrative description.

The mourning actions—casting dust on heads, wallowing in ashes—are conventional symbolic gestures. They are literal acts but function symbolically as physical metaphors for grief and humiliation; I treat the pair together as one figurative complex.

instances.english_text: They shall cast dust on their heads and strew ashes on themselves (lit. ‘wallow themselves in ashes’)
target: the mourners’ inner anguish over Tyre’s fall
vehicle: covering oneself with dust and ashes, wallowing in them
ground: being low, dirty, and as if near the grave expresses deep sorrow and shame
posture: maximally dramatizing the lament over Tyre
instances.explanation: Throwing dust on the head and wallowing in ashes are literal actions that function as symbolic, hyperbolic metaphors of grief and humiliation, enacting the mourners’ inner devastation.

deliberation: Again mourning actions are mentioned, along with 'in bitterness of soul'. The latter is a clear metaphor, as the ‘soul’ is described as bitter to convey deep emotional pain.

instances.english_text: brokenhearted (lit. ‘with bitterness of soul’)
target: the mourners’ emotional state over Tyre
ground: both bitterness in taste and grief feel harsh, painful, and hard to bear
posture: underscoring the severity of the lament
instances.explanation: Describing their ‘soul’ as bitter uses taste imagery to metaphorically convey the sharp, painful quality of their grief.

deliberation: The lament question, 'Who was like Tyre, like one silenced/destroyed in the midst of the sea?' explicitly employs simile, likening Tyre to a shattered entity in the sea, within the ongoing shipwreck imagery.

instances.english_text: Who was like Tyre, like one silenced/destroyed in the midst of the sea?
vehicle: a being or vessel struck dumb/shattered in the middle of the sea
ground: both are suddenly brought from prominence to utter ruin and quiet in a perilous place
shock of abrupt cessation in a dramatic location
posture: rhetorically highlighting the unparalleled nature of Tyre’s ruin
instances.explanation: The verse uses a simile—‘like one silenced/destroyed in the midst of the sea’—to compare Tyre’s fate to that of a suddenly wrecked entity at sea, amplifying the horror of her fall.

deliberation: The verse says Tyre 'satisfied many peoples' and 'enriched kings'. 'Satisfy' uses alimentary language metaphorically for meeting economic needs on a large scale.

instances.english_text: You satisfied many peoples
target: Tyre’s role in supplying goods and wealth
vehicle: feeding people until they are full
ground: both providing food and providing goods remove lack and create a sense of sufficiency
posture: acknowledging Tyre’s former beneficent impact before judging her
instances.explanation: ‘Satisfying’ peoples uses the metaphor of feeding to describe how Tyre’s trade met the needs of many nations abundantly.

deliberation: The language of being 'broken from the seas' and sinking in 'deep waters' resumes the shipwreck metaphor for Tyre’s collapse.

instances.english_text: But when you were wrecked on the seas, in the deep waters
target: the destruction and disappearance of Tyre and her commerce
vehicle: a ship broken and sinking in the depths of the sea
ground: both involve being overwhelmed and lost in a vast, engulfing environment
posture: underscoring the drastic reversal from prosperity to oblivion
instances.explanation: The phrase depicts Tyre’s end as a shipwreck in deep waters, a metaphor emphasizing the comprehensive and irrecoverable nature of her fall.

deliberation: The reactions—being appalled, shuddering, faces showing horror—are vivid but express normal human response; phraseology is not distinctly figurative beyond standard emotional description.

Two main figurative elements stand out: (1) 'You have become a horror/terror'—Tyre now personifies terror for others; (2) 'You are no more forever'—a hyperbolic idiom for irreversible desolation. These are related but distinct expressions (reputation vs. continued existence).

instances.english_text: You have become a horror (lit. ‘terrors’)
target: Tyre’s post-destruction reputation among the nations
vehicle: ‘terrors’ as objects or experiences that inspire fear
ground: Tyre now serves as something that causes dread and astonishment
her fate is terrifying to contemplate
posture: using Tyre as a warning exemplar
instances.explanation: Calling Tyre ‘terrors’ personifies her fate: she has become an embodiment of horror, a frightening example to others.

instances.english_text: and you have ceased to be forever (lit. ‘you are not, forever’)
target: the enduring loss of Tyre as a political power
ground: Tyre will never return to her former status; she is as good as nonexistent
posture: stressing the irrevocability of divine judgment
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘you are not, forever’ hyperbolically portrays Tyre’s destruction as permanent non-existence, conveying total and irreversible desolation.
